p: The species reproduces from seeds, which can produce up to 200,000 per year depending on the habitat [ 49], but so far this has been observed only in the native places of occurrence, namely in Asia and Europe. Some biotypes of this plant do not produce reproductive seeds [ 5]. The seeds of A. vulgaris spread through wind, beetles, and flies [ 47]. The plant usually reproduces vegetatively with the help of its roots, which can survive in the ground during winter. In the northern USA, pieces of roots are often moved long distances by local floods [ 7].
